messageBody:
oliver langan scripsit:

> Almost as easy, except for the key differences in orthography: Shavian
> uses two characters for schwa (ADO and UP), where Quickscript uses
> only UTTER: which code point do we use? Do we encode UTTER at both
> code points?

Unification cannot provide automatic transliteration, except in very
special cases like Serbian Cyrillic to Latin, and even then it requires
the font to have special digraphs for "lj", "nj", and "dž" on the
Latin side that exist in Unicode but aren't normally used. Unification
reduces the number of code points while still allowing bare legibility.
For example, Spanish ó and Polish ó are unified in Unicode because
it is possible to use the same shape for the letter in both languages,
though in fine Polish typography the ´ is stubbier and shorter than in
Spanish, a problem that can be solved by using Polish fonts for Polish
and Spanish fonts for Spanish.

By that standard, UTTER should be unified with ADO, not with UP. Per
contra, HAVE should not be unified with HA-HA: the shapes are too
different for that.

> That would lead to the same word having two different
> (but visually indistinguishable) spellings, which would be problematic
> for machine translation.

Actually, machine translation could handle it with ease. It's searching
that would require special treatment.

--
No, John. I want formats that are actually John Cowan
useful, rather than over-featured megaliths that http://www.ccil.org/~cowan
address all questions by piling on ridiculous cowan@...
internal links in forms which are hideously
over-complex. --Simon St. Laurent on xml-dev
